info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued January 22 at 2:54PM MST by NWS Albuquerque
info.description: ...SNOWFALL TONIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT MAY CREATE SLICK TRAVEL OVER WESTERN AND CENTRAL MOUNTAINS ABOVE 7,500 FEET... Several upper level winter disturbances will continue to move over or near New Mexico this week, producing rounds of light snowfall over high terrain areas of western and central New Mexico, including the Chuska, Tusas, Jemez, Sangre de Cristo, Sandia and Manzano, and Sacramento Mountains as well as the peaks of the Gila tonight through Tuesday night. Light amounts of a dusting to an inch will favor lower elevations of 6,000 to 7,500 feet, with a few inches between 7,500 to 8,500 feet and atop the peaks of the northern mountains. Locally higher amounts up to a foot or more will be isolated to the higher peaks of the Gila NF and Sierra Blanca by Ruidoso above 9,500 feet. Motorists should exercise caution, be prepared for rapidly changing visibilities and slick roadways. Allow extra time to reach your destination. For the latest road conditions, dial 511 or 1.800.432.4269, or visit nmroads.com.
